EU's AI Act takes effect, sparking new Europe-US clash
subhead: Key parts of the legislation governing artificial intelligence came into force on Saturday. Washington and American tech giants have not given up on their coordinated offensive against this law and, more broadly, against European digital regulation.

title: Former PM Gabriel Attal wants to make his mark with a  name change for Macron's Renaissance party
subhead: Gabriel Attal, former prime minister and current head of Emmanuel Macron's Renaissance party, sent questions to Renaissance members on July 31 about the party's future and name, as a way to redefine its identity and shape it to suit him ahead of the 2027 presidential election.

title: Up to a million young Catholics in Rome for Pope Leo vigil
subhead: The 'Jubilee of Youth' – when the Vatican invites Catholics aged 18 to 35 to the seat of the global Church's power – has brought thousands of young pilgrims from around the world to Rome this week. The night-time vigil on Saturday is the culmination of this week-long pilgrimage.

title: French swimmer Maxime Grousset clinches third world title in butterfly
subhead: After taking gold in the 50m butterfly on Monday, Grousset once again became a world champion in the 100m butterfly in Singapore on Saturday. This double victory, along with new French and European records, has confirmed his talent in a stroke that was never his main focus.

title: How France's 1975 amicable divorce law transformed gender relations
subhead: On July 11, 1975, France authorized divorce by mutual consent, marking a turning point for couples.

title: 'West Berlin became my street': Emine Sevgi Özdamar, Turkish factory worker turned actress
subhead: 'Being 20 in West Berlin' (5/6). Writer, actress and theater director, the now 60-something Emine Sevgi Özdamar arrived in Germany from Turkey as a young woman to work in a factory. Very quickly, the aspiring actress discovered a new way of making theater.

title: Locals in Mexico City rise up against gentrification
subhead: Soaring rents in the Mexican capital have driven hundreds of residents into the streets to protest against property speculation, a shortage of housing and the arrival of 'digital nomads' in certain neighborhoods.
